page.title: 06WATERWAYS AND RECREATION
page.content: The Bridgwater Canal today is polluted with rubbish and green algae. Near the canal, as it approaches the docks, are some quite large terraced houses built with red bricks and tiles made in Bridgwater when brick and tile making were major industries (industries that continued until the late 1960s.) The hedges bordering the canal provides homes for birds and the banks for water voles. In the canal are eels, pike, tench and rudd. Angling and canoeing are two popular recreations. It is planned to restore the canal so that more light boats can be used on it. Alongside the canal, near the red bricked terraced houses, are allotments on which are grown potatoes,carrots,beans, lettuce and other vegetables. At quiet times of the day it is sometimes possible to see a heron or a kingfisher.
